pros: Good compensation, flexible scheduling, and beautiful campus
cons: Facilities could be more up-to-date

pros: This organization takes care of the whole person.
cons: It is a small teaching college so if you want to have research it is really hard to get started because there is no start-up funds and the teaching load is heavy.

review_title: We are millions in debt and it's only a matter of time before we close.
pros: I can't think of anything except for the students that are tricked into coming here They come with the best intentions and soon realize it was a huge mistake- no one cares about them- we just need the money. Beware!!!!
cons: We don't live the mission, it's the worst- Leadership(dishonest), Staff(backstabbing) Facility's (mold and falling apart) Education (It's a joke) - everything is so awful. Anyone that is any good realizes it quick and gets out. The only folks working here- don't have other options.

review_title: Fair Work, But Little Pay, No Prospects
pros: Gorgeous Campus Comfortable Classrooms Full Freedom in Course Design Fairly Friendly Students Some Very Nice Colleagues
cons: Poor Pay Pressured by Some Students to Give Higher Scores You're Excluded as an Adjunct in Faculty Activities You're Ignored by the Administration It's a 'dead-end' job...get to applying elsewhere while you work

pros: Small community with plenty of opportunities to collaborate. Being small, establishing and maintaining relationships is essential.
cons: Never ending financial woes. High turnover. Being short staffed means assisting in a lot of other areas. The last few years have resulted in positions, benefits, and salaries being cut. If you're starting out, this could be a great place to gain experience for a year or two.

pros: Professors take time with their students.
cons: The school is very small.

pros: Not a hard job, easily mastered

job_title: Data Entry Clerk in Mobile, AL
pros: There are no more pros

pros: Some of the best people to work with!
cons: Pay and benefits are not the best.

review_title: Great colleagues, great mission, dead-end job
pros:
My colleagues were amazing - they truly cared about student success and were wonderful to work with! 
The mission of Spring Hill College is also incredible: a refreshing change from the purely job focused goals of many other colleges and universities.
cons:
Little to no support for professional development. 
Salaries were extremely low to begin with, and administration kept threatening to cut them further. There was no hope of even a COLA, and promotions carried marginal salary increases - so working here, you basically earn less each year. 
Workload here was extremely high, compared to similar jobs. 
It seemed as though the mission was only for students, not faculty and staff: administration did not care about employee concerns or take steps to correct them. 
Low employee morale did not make the workplace a positive environment; we were also continually understaffed due to high employee turnover.

pros: Beautiful campus. Great and noble mission. Great students. Board of Trustees very invested. Jesuit schools' network = very good. Amazing tuition benefit for employees + families with the opportunity to apply for the same benefit at other Jesuit schools. The recent leadership change and the COO/President structure = reason to be hopeful. Generally good people, with many who are amazing in their ability to accomplish great things with limited resources. People who step up can acquire resume fodder that'll take them to the next level. Faculty contracts = early August through mid-May with voluntary summer classes.
cons: Generally understaffed and resource deprived. Heavily tuition dependent. Salary cut across the board in 2008, later restored, but no salary increase since. Some morale issues. Under market salaries according to most comparison sets, except lowest hourly rates at "living wage" not minimum wage.  Leans too heavily on too few people. Burnout can occur. Hasn't been investing enough in faculty/staff professional development.

review_title: A Delightful Place with Great People--But No Job is Perfect
job_title: Assistant Professor, Humanities in Mobile, AL
pros: Fantastic colleagues, respect from peers and supervisors, strong religious values; no micro-management; freedom in the classroom to experiment for the sake of increasing effectiveness; great students; small community with lots of interpersonal interaction.
cons: Lower-than-average compensation; lack of openness regarding budget; talk of shared governance is mostly talk rather than genuine commitment.

review_title: All about the mission, even if you're not a Jesuit.
pros: Very collegial atmostphere with relatively little of the sniping typical in academia. Good teaching is valued, even required for tenure. The students tend to be above average.
cons: Crappy pay. Most faculty with any publications and/or administration experience are on the market. Very little support for academic pursuits. Any research done is strictly because you love it, not because it will get you rewarded or acknowledged. The college is financially hanging on by a thread.

pros: It's a Beautiful place.  They really care about the students needs. They also offer a wonderful benefits package.
cons: Unfortunately some of the management as far as the operations department need to be observed more closely for many reasons.  Also the drama that is allowed makes it a somewhat difficult work environment.

pros: Very nice people and great colleagues. The students tend to be above average. Pretty campus.
cons: The pay rate for faculty is abyssal. When I was at SHC there were faculty on the market all the time. Essentially the old-timers have stayed because they have nothing else or a spouse makes the big money. But for younger and unmarried faculty, the paltry pay was an insult. What never seemed to get through to the administration is that the faculty were not Jesuits and did not take a vow of poverty.

pros:
If you can manage to find the right people, they make your time at the college 100% worth it.
The benefits package was truly top notch - until they took away retirement contribution matching and made everyone's medical coverage HDHP.
Students get an amazing education. The faculty spends so much time developing an immersive curriculum that teaches valuable life lessons.
Staff and faculty alike care immensely for the well-being and development of students.
cons:
Weak management from soup to nuts. 
Miscommunication on all levels, there is a strange element of "secrecy" from upper admin.
Financial stability is nonexistent. This school was released from probation with SACS by divine mercy; definitely not because of financial improvement. 
A majority of the power lies within the hands of a small handful of people, who withhold information from the President and Board, who think that everyone loves working at Spring Hill.
If there is an issue the Vice Presidents run and cry to the President at the drop of a hat. 
Enrollment is steadily decreasing despite what they tell prospective employees and current employees at assemblies. 
Not one person in power wants to be held accountable for mistakes (including SACS probation). Everything is always someone else to blame for the College's problems.
There is no trust on the most basic of levels. Supervisors log into their supervisees email accounts and look for gossip and reasons to let people go.

pros:
Great atmosphere to work in
Beautiful historic campus
Wonderful coworkers
Whether you're religeous or not, Ignatian Spirituality and thoughts are excellent business guidelines
cons:
Financial struggles make job security a little unstable
Some of the students can be a challenge to deal with
Jobs at Spring Hill tend to ask for a bit more from you than elsewhere

pros: I am a student so the is not much to talk about. I really do like the small environment. Lots of nice people
cons: The pay here at spring hill college is really low and I need to find a real job. Make money

pros: Education provided is a very high level. The Campus and other resources have great potential.
cons: The School didn't seem to utilize its own Business Department when it came to making decisions. Poor Miss management in many areas lead to a sever money issue.

pros:
New president is pretty darn amazing. VERY HOPEFUL!
Raises this year!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Second largest freshman class ever. 
Great mission
Great students
Great tuition benefit
cons:
You have to love teaching and service and make time for research. 
Yes 4/4 load, but faculty do control the workloads within courses - for themselves and their students.

pros: Great colleagues and low pressure work environment
cons: Lowest salary among colleges in the state. Poor transparency from the administration

review_title: Wonderful working environment with supportive coworkers.
job_title: Student Center Associate in Mobile, AL
pros: Very flexible hours, gets you even more immersed into the Badger culture, meet tons of people, and gain powerful allies.
cons: If it's the student center, you may have to work till 2am on a Saturday night.

review_title: If This College Were Stock, I Would Not Buy It
pros: Catholic, supposed commitment to education, intimate community
cons: Poor management, cuts in pay and benefits, excessive demands on faculty

pros: Community, faith, Christianity, student relations
cons: High work load, no sabbaticals, weak I.T.

pros: Beautiful campus and many activities for the employees

pros: Tight knit office, professional development, world class recruiting team
cons: Sometimes there can be a lack of communication from leaders down the line.

pros: Nice environment and beautiful campus
cons: There is no room for advancement/promotion

pros: Comraderie among professors and teaching commitment among professors
cons: Low pay, no raises and even pay cuts; no sabbaticals and limited travel money; too many administrators for school its size; provost who cares little about faculty and "plays favorites," constant budget crisis.

pros: Past Record of Achievement and Strength
